DOC.UNK: FTC Clears Icahn to Acquire Bigger Stake in USX Corp.
DOC.TEXT: Federal antitrust regulators have cleared investor Carl C. Icahn to acquire a bigger stake in USX Corp., the Federal Trade Commission said Tuesday. The agency said it had granted Icahn early termination of the waiting period required under federal law to ensure that certain mergers and acquisitions do not violate antitrust law. Icahn, known for his past corporate takeover attempts, also owns Trans World Airlines Inc. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission last month, Icahn revealed he was seeking FTC permission to acquire at least 25 percent of USX, a Pittsburgh-based steel and energy company. FTC clearance for such an acquisition is required under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act. The FTC announced Icahn's acquisition of USX was among the transactions granted clearance, or early termination from the waiting period. No other information was provided by the FTC. USX spokesman William Kessler declined to comment on Icahn's filing. Icahn was in meetings Tuesday, his secretary said. He did not immediately return calls seeking comment. Icahn's November SEC filing showed he owned nearly 34 million, or 13.26 percent, of USX's outstanding shares of common stock. The document said Icahn intended to acquire more than 15 percent of USX's voting securities ``and, depending upon market conditions, more than 25 percent'' of its voting securities. The filing said the acquisition was dependent on market conditions and redemption or invalidation of a ``poison pill'' shareholder rights plan adopted by USX on Oct. 10 in an attempt to ward off a hostile takeover.
